awd_titl_txt: EAGER: A Novel Carbon Nanotube Based Phosphate Sensor Using Potentiometric Principles for Oceanographic Use
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI's request EAGER funding to build a phosphate sensor for aquatic systems. Phosphate and Nitrate are essential macronutrients limiting primary productivity in most aquatic ecosystems. The availability of phosphate, a main component of the marine biological carbon pump strongly influences the ability to capture and store the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide. Development of a phosphate sensor with high precision, long lifetime, low detection limit, and good reproducibility would improve estuarine and coastal water quality monitoring and further understanding of marine nutrient cycling. If successful, these phosphate sensors could have far reaching impact for a range of other applications. The PI's envision an array of low cost, low power sensors fitting onto the sensor surface the size of a quarter.

The PI's propose to build and characterize a carbon nanotube based potentiometric phosphate sensor. This prototype sensor will allow the PI's to test the sensors response, its sensitivity and lower selection limit and long-term performance in the lab and field testing at the dock. With other funding the PI’s have been developing a potentiometric Chloride sensor. They plan to follow a similar strategy for developing the proposed potentiometric phosphate sensor. The goal is to be able to produce a small, low cost, accurate, in situ phosphate sensor to provide the needed data on spatial and temporal scales necessary to answer questions not possible with current technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of South Carolina, School of the Earth, Ocean and Env

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

With the sensor suite available today, scientists have a difficult path to spatial and temporal oceanographic data with resolution on scales necessary to answer topical questions. One of the parameters that cannot be measured with sufficient accuracy is phosphate. Yet, phosphates, along with nitrogen, are essential macronutrients limiting primary productivity in most aquatic ecosystems. The availability of phosphate, which is a main component of the marine biological carbon pump, thus strongly influences the sequestration of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide. Developing a low cost phosphate sensor with sufficiently high precision, long lifetime, low detection limit and good reproducibility would allow improved estuarine and coastal water quality monitoring and further our understanding of marine nutrient cycling, which ultimately impacts primary productivity, ecosystem structure, and global climate.

The overarching goal of this project is to explore whether and how solid-state potentiometry can be used for small, low-power, and low-cost measurements in oceanography. We are doing so by using a carbon nanotube transducer and ion-selective membranes for phosphate detection. 

The significant results obtained as part of this project are:

1. A semi-automated sensor fabrication of cobalt based phosphate sensors using silk-screening and capillary pen-induced printing was developed. With further development, the fabrication protocol could be developed for full automation. 

2. Barium-based potentiometric sensors did not show consistent and reproducible response to phosphate ions.

3. Cobalt-wire-based sensors did not show sensitivity below 10-6M, which was consistent with previous papers.

4. We achieved the best detection limit of a phosphate sensor in comparison to prior arts using the Cobalt/ SWCNT approach. Cobalt powder mixed with single-walled carbon nanotubes showed a detection limit of 10-7M, which could improve the detection limit by 10 folds in comparison to previous art. According to our test results, the detection limit could be enhanced a few times, which will be between 10-8 and 10-7M, according to our characterization. The major enhancement of the detection limit resulted from using cobalt powder mixed with single-walled carbon nanotubes directly without an ion-selective membrane. In the future, error bars can be reduced by improving the carbon nanotube dispersion and the uniform pasting step of the detection layer.

Broader impacts:

The focus of this project was developping a small, low-power, and low-cost phosphate sensor for researchers working in freshwater and marine environments. With further development, we believe that this sensor could be found on future scientific cruises as a tool for limonogists and potentially oceanographers, depending on the effects of salinity on sensor performance. Due to the high sensitivity and detection limit (<0.1 uM), the sensing technology will impact phosphate detection in fresh water for analyzing water contamination.


Last Modified: 09/05/2024
Modified by: Annie Bourbonnais
